The Russian Ambassador had issued cards Of
invitation to the number OF 300 or 900 for grand
ball to be given on the 22d of February. The
Marshals of France are all addressed by their IL
ties and not by their names, as was the case
when invited by the Austrian Ambassador.

rived at Marseilles on the 9th Of Feb. and de-

covered with snow, about the 1st of February,
that the authorities of the villages at their feet
and on their sides, cause bells to be rung night
and day, to acquaint travellers OF their approach
TO inhabited places, the communications between
which are totally interrupted

am pleased that "Lodge Hip has again

The success of the High School for Girls,
| in New York, equals the expectations ot its
most sanguine advocates. No establish
ment of the kind has edited US more in its
general aspect and routine. In the three
great divisions, comprising several hundred
female children of respectable parcnts--the
monitorial system is applied with rcmarka
Bile order, facility, and advantage -Besdes
the usual rudiments of the best English cd
ucaton, needle work of every kind, French,
and drawing are effcctually taught; and 1t
has been found BY the intelligent ladies who
preside over the School, and who have had
much experience in the common acadamies
that nothing is lost in this institution with
respect to manners and morals. Notwith'
. standing the number of the pupils, the dis
cpline in fact may be such as to product
the habit of greater proprety and dclicacl
Of demeanor. We mention these particu
lars now. merely to excite public atten
tion to the subject; sincerely wishing tina
the good example of New-York, in the for
nation of the Female High School, may b
followed here as readily and beneficially a


it has been in the case of the High Schoo


for boys.

will be repaired and ref,'ed Immediately
and proceed on her voyage to Napoli di Ro-

TO MISS Il,
Who sa,u in Church raise her eyes toccards He
oh, Lady! when saw thy eyes
Ras'd meekly to the vault above;
And fix their gaze upon the skies,
They seemed to beam a soul love;
A soul endued with every grace
That can enrich the human face.
felt (it was sacred glow
A holy calm perrade my breast.
That babe my spirits lightest flow,
Pass sweetly in untroubled rest,


And bid each wayward care depart,
That nestled in my youthful heart,
And when the herald ofthc Lord,
Proclaimed the Gospel truths as given
And feeling dwelt upon the word,
The mandate of the God Of ofl,eaven,--
o! then ChriStiun'S hope divine,
Seemd cherish'd in that soul Of thine
And as gazed intent on thee,
l felt passing throe of bliss,
Then mouIn'd TO think it could not be
Continued in world like this,


Where every source OF pleasure here,
Is mingled with c6'iction's tear.
Yes, lady, fate doth bid me say,
Ere long ! go, and know not where's
Vet oft will recall the day


saw thee thus engaged in prayer


O, yes, and then this soul oi mine,
viii ask blessing down on thine.

The cure for intemperance, advertised in
most of our city papers, has produced good
many inquiries as to its real effect and utill-
ty. The editor of the New York Observer
mentions for the satisfaction of his distant
correspondents, several cases OF complete
cure following the use of the medicine, One
of these was that of woman between SO and
90 years of age, who had been incorporate
tor 25 years, and who. on taking the medi-
cine four times, lost all desire tor intoHcat-
ing liquors. Another was that of silver
smith, who found the remedy so ettectual,
that he presented the Doctor a set OF silver
spoons in addition to the usual fee. A third
is that of a man whose wife gave the medi-
cine to a neighbor where her husband used
to call for his liquor, with request that 1t
might be mixed with his drink. a few
draughts at different times made the man
saw that he did "not know what was the
matter with him, but somehow he was not
dry" 1t is said that taking the medicine
once or twice is commonly sufficient; but
that in some obstinate Cases it has failed to
effect a cure.

Yyon, who lately published his Journal OF the
northern expedition while in command OF
one Of Capt. Parrv's ships, has met with sc.
yere rcverses Of fortune. Having received
an appointment in ono OF the Mexican min

every thing he had Soon after landing, he
was informed of the death OF his amiable and
accomplished wife.

The "Echo du Mido" states, that new
era is about to break out in Spain. The e.
Vacuation of the capital by the Swiss regim-
ehts is regarded, it saws, as the prelude to
me French army quitting Spain altogether,
ana evacuating Cadiz, Pampeuna, St. Sc.
oaStan, and Barcelona. This is a consum-
nation to be wished. A clear field for ac-
uon would then begin in Spain. and Ferdin-
ana would have to look to it; for his goodly
Alhgdom would be on weak foundation.

1t is said that the articles were in great va
riety and of superior workmanship. The
broad cloths, cassimcrcs, tlannels and satin
etts, were in great quantities. OF cotton
goods sheetng, shirtings and printed cali
Goes, there was also an extensive assortment.
Some of them very hnc, and the colours and
figures of the prints very good. Articles OF
glass s-ware and cabinet furniture were MI
merous; and some fine ware in imitation OF
China, was offered. There were, likewise,
great quantities of wool, leather and shoes
The sales, we understand, were generally
made at fair prices.

The first corner stone Ct the Pennsylvania
State Canal was laid at Harrisburg last
week, with masonic ceremonies, IN the
presence of the members of the legislature
and the masonic fraternity OF the vicinity,
who. together with the Governor, heads OF
departments, and several distinguished vls,
itors. among whom were Governor Carroll
OF Tennessee, aud Messrs. Findlay and
Marks. oe the United States Senate, march
ed in procession. from the State Capitol to
the canal. A short and appropriate address
was delivered on the occasion. by Joseph
Rinter. Esq. the Speaker of the House OF
Representatives.

Road Company were subscribed between
zen and two o'clock. on the tirst day OF the
onenng Of the books.

full articles.headline: FOREIGN 1NrHLL1GENCE.
full articles.article:
The Russian Ambassador had issued cards Of
invitation to the number OF 300 or 900 for grand
ball to be given on the 22d of February. The
Marshals of France are all addressed by their IL
ties and not by their names, as was the case
when invited by the Austrian Ambassador.


The nun cipal authorities of Paris have ap.
propriated "a, 900 francs for an extraordinary dis
tibution among the INDECENT of that city.


The Prince Royal of Denmark and suite, ar
rived at Marseilles on the 9th Of Feb. and de-
parted on the 9th for Toulon.


Ii is said to be the intention of the British Ad-
mlralty, to build six steam ships ot the largest
size, capable of carrying 200 carronade guns OF
increased caliber, and to be propelled By two en-
gnes of two hundred horse power each.


A letter of the 1st February, from Mcnde de-
partment Of I.osere, announces that Is persons
have persisted in the snow. 1t is apprehendcd
that still greater number will be found when
the snow mcits.


The mountains Of Saxony werc SO completely
covered with snow, about the 1st of February,
that the authorities of the villages at their feet
and on their sides, cause bells to be rung night
and day, to acquaint travellers OF their approach
TO inhabited places, the communications between
which are totally interrupted
| a letter from Trieste gives intelligence OF
naval combat having taken place to the
south of the Morea, between the trlSate liei-
las. built at NewYork for the Greeks, and
an Ottoman feet of small vessels ot war.-
The frigate sunk a Turkish schooner and
thirteen large boats, aud then entered Napo-
Ii de Romania amidst the discharge OF can
non ard the acclamat,ons of the people.


Several persons of distinction have aied
in consequence of colds caught at the funer-
al of the Duke of York. The Duke OF Sus-
sex, and MIR. Canning are indisposed from
the same cause.


The prosecution of Mr.. Shiel, tor "trea-
sonable speech" delivered before the Cath-
olic association, has excited much sensation
in Ireland


Various outrages have lately been com
mitted at Carlisle, England, and to such ex-
tent carried, that according to the West
moreland Advertiser, when friends meet ID
the streets, instead of inquiring after eaco
others health, the first question they put Is
"Wcre you robbed last night!"


A work has appeared in London. as Sc
ouel to the Percy Anecdotes, entitled Anec-
dotes of Impudence, with portrait OF MT
Hume, M. p. III,
The Liverpool Mercury says, the puoll'
debt OF England, which in 1915, amounted Z
6oO, 900, 900 pounds, on the 5th OF January


1927, amounted to 900, ,0o0,o 600 pounds.

full articles.headline: Public Sale. to Close Concern
full articles.article:
The Subscribers will offer for sale at public
vendue on Tuesday, the Sd day of April, all thef
stock ofSTORE GOODS, consisting Of gen
cral assortment of all kinds of DRY GOODS and
GROCERIES; calicoes, domestic musns, plaids,
cloths, fannels, clothing Of all kinds, such as
coats, pantaloons, vests, shirts, hats, &c. Shoes
and boots; teas, sugar, coffee, pepper, rice;
crockery, earthen and tin ware. A good assort-
ment Of Carpenter'stoo tools: saws, planes, augers,
rules, chissels, etc


kitchen furniture; one horse cart and harness,
and frame dwelling house, 18 by "a, standing
on the south east corner of Hugh Extons farm,
on the road leading to Delaware city, to be re-
moved off of the ground when sold. Vendue to
commence at 10 O'Clock, and conditions made
known by


Fl. EXToN, SONS & CO.
Red Lion, March 90, 1927. 28-ts.

The North River is not yet entirely clear OF
ice.


A School of Sculpture is about 20 be establish
cd in New York, by MIR. j. II. Browerc.


UIot otmM?-A new paper has been estab-
liehcd at Rochester, N. Y. to be devoted en-.
trelv to the publication Of matters connected
with the Morgan business.


A line of packets has been established be-
tween lIavr,, and Brazil, to sail for Pernan,buc-
co every Six weeks


The widow OF Capt. Cook, the celebrated clr
cumnayigator, is still living;


Commodore Bainbridge, on quitting hi
off ial situation at Washington, AS Preslden
of the Naval Board, which will be III jun'
next, will return to his old tavorite city
Philadelphia.


The health fees on foreign vessels arriving
at the port of Philadelphia for the last year
accounted to $3.50; the head money on for.
egn personascs, Sl,q74.


The Boston Traveller os the 1ith, states
that in the ship Majestic, arrived at Boston
last week, from Liverpool, came passengers
six calico printers. one of them accompanied
by his wife and five children. They are tc
be settled at Dover, n. II. and to be employ.
ed in the Factory in that place.
The Rec. Ezra Butler, who has append
cd to his name, the title OF CQtidm Genera
and Commander in Chief in aud over the
State of Vermont, has issued his proclama-
ton, appointing the dth of April, a day oi
humiliation fasting and prayer.


A man Of the name of Petty, committed
suicide few days ago, in the neighborhoot
of Bclvidere, n j., by cutting his throat, il
the presence of his mother wife and sever
children. He had been laboring under ma
MIA potu for some time previous to tht
dreadful occurrence.
| The Corporation of AIl!ejgeville, Geo.
laws "A tax of twenty-five dollars upon every
free person of color, coming into that tow
with an intention OF working therein.


The Senate OF Louisiana have passed
resolution, inviting Gen. Jackson to partici
pate with the citizens of New Orleans il
1 celebrating the next anniversary of the Bat
tie at that place.


During the reign of Francis !. there wer
ONLY two coaches in Paris, lone belonging t
the Queen, and the other to Diana OF PoIc
tiers Men and women rode on horseback
the greatest lords carried their wives hchin
them; and this custom lasted until the md
die of the 18th century.


The Supreme Court ofthe u. s. at Wash
ington, has adjourned to the next term, hay
ing decided and dismissed in all II cause!
leaving on the docket for the next term 10
causes.


A man in New-Hampshire lately hange
himself after making his preparations wit
much sang froid. He took bundle of tia
to neighbor's and broke it; he went to an
others and swingled it; to thirds and mad
a rope He went home and hanged him
self.


The North Carolina, "A, bound down tn
straits. was seen off the west of end of Sar
dinia, on the 10th Jan.


The rival oyster companies OF New Ier
sev have gone to law This is great tol
lly. The lawyers will swallow all the mea
and leave the the members nothing but tn
shells.

am pleased that "Lodge Hip has again
turned out to air and sun himself. His as
pect since appears reasonably mild, and his
feshy parts scarcely rufled. and should
not have had to charge blame to his account
had he not drawn or suffered to crawl out
of his hole in the hill, strange figured fierce
looking something to frighten US, which in
shape, though not in size, answers very we'll
to late description of an animal called the
"sea serpent" Its many protuburances and
admirable length gives it very suspicious
appearance. Yet there are still doubts whe-
ther it is amphibious or not; at any rate IT 1t
proves dangerous to the community. it will
be very easy matter to dissect its head
from its body in the manner | have cut OH
all the mines in my example. Next we VIII
subtract and sub subtract, till we ascertain
the value of the body itself; and, lastly, cut
off long string off of the tail and count it Of
little value.


Now as my neighbour over Brandywint
appears to be very solicitous to receive IN
struction from me, therefore, knowing my
self to be his good friend, propose that h'
ion himself to our Eastern brethern ant
learn the art of fishing in deep waters.

full articles.headline: Bartram's Botanic Garden,
full articles.article:
The Subscriber respectfully informs the Pub
lie, that he has nom for sale, at reduced priees q
very extensive assortment of the finest
FRUIT TREES,


ORNAMENTAL TREES, AND
SHRUBS;


GREEN HOUSE PLANTS,
HARDY HERBACEOUS PLANTS,
BULBOUS ROOTS,


GRAPE VINES, &c. &c.


Among the Bruit Trees are several hundred OF
the finest PEAR, PLUM, and APRICOT Trees
imported by the subscriber last spring, direct
from one of the first Nurseries of Paris They
are of large size, and in excellent order for
planting out,
| Also, fine large CHERRY and PEACH Trees.
! 10000 fine healthy APPLE Trees
5000 GRAPE VINES, of 100 varities-Strong
healthy plants, cultivated in pots, and fit to
plant out with safety.
The GREEN HOUSE collection amounts to
, nearly 10000 plants, in pots and tubs, and in
/ cudes all the varieties of elegant plantsusua lily
/ cultivated Amongst the number are upwards
Of 400 Camclias of 81 varieties, 600 Cape Jas
mines of several varieties, Green and Bohea Tea
Trees, White Moss Roses, Tea Scented Roses,
&c.


The GRAPE VINES are particularly deserv3
ing the attention of the public, the collection
includes nearly all the finest Grapes of France
and Germany, that will stand this climate, with
number of fine Hungarian Grapes from Tokay,
imported for the subscriber, and which produced,
last season, the most delicious fruit, they per-
fectly hardy, and bear well.


Cuttings of the Bland or Poval Grape Vine
and Of the fine Wine Grape, called Alexander or
ScHUYLKILL MuscADEL (also called SpRINeMTLL
CoSsrAsrIA) for sale at fifty cents per dozen,
two dollars per hundred, or fifteen dollars per
| 1000.


| The .1pple Trees and Grape FINES are equal in
qualty 10 any imported from the Long Island Nur-
series, aad arc sold third cheaper than the pri
ces charged by those Nurseries.


Catalogues may be had at either of the follow
ing places, yis;-Alderman G. Bartram's, No. 68
South Second Street; Thomas Lloyd's corner of
Market and Eight-streets; at the Stall, Nc.
40, opposite Decatur street, or at stall, No. S,
New Market, below Pine streets; at either of
which places orders may be left and all orders,
per mail, OF otherwise, will be promptly attend
ed TO- and the articles delivered in Philadelphia,
or shipped to order.


Strangers visiting Philadelphia, respect
fully invited TO view the Garden, which is situat-
cd on the west bank of the Schuylkll, half a
mile below Gray's Ferry, miles from the Cen
tire Square.


ROBERT CARR.
| March %. 28-4t.

full articles.headline: GRADUATED JUSTICE.
full articles.article:
In a certain village, i'll New York, where
the footsteps of Dame Justice were last seen
ON earth, it happened on warm summers
day, that three men were brought before
fair. round Dutch Magistrate, accused OF
the crime Of drunkenness His honor hav-
ing promised with hearty swig OF cool
punch, began with the frst-"iou rascal
pe you kitty, or pc you not kitty!


Pris.--Guilty.


Just.--Nat YOU get trunk on


Pris-Black strap.


Just.-Nat you get trunk on noting Dut
backstrap, you villain, you Den, DIS pc
mine everlasting sentence, dat you pc hned
40 shillings.


The second culprit being questioned in
like manner, as 10 his guilt or innocence,
likewise owned himself guilty.


Just-Now tell me, yon vile, trunken
rascal! vat you get trunk on
Pris.-Slng.


Just.-Nat YOU get trunk on sling, you
graceless wagabont you swillin' sod, you
Den give my darnal sentence, that you pc
fined 20 shillings.


The third and last prisoner was now
brought forward, and, like the other, plead
guilty


Jnsr.-vat YOU get trunk on
! Pris-Punuh.


! Just.-Ah YOU dpplin' rogue, YOU fines
YOU Just noting at all, vor | gets trunk on
punch minesel:, sometimes.


The success of the High School for Girls,
| in New York, equals the expectations ot its
most sanguine advocates. No establish
ment of the kind has edited US more in its
general aspect and routine. In the three
great divisions, comprising several hundred
female children of respectable parcnts--the
monitorial system is applied with rcmarka
Bile order, facility, and advantage -Besdes
the usual rudiments of the best English cd
ucaton, needle work of every kind, French,
and drawing are effcctually taught; and 1t
has been found BY the intelligent ladies who
preside over the School, and who have had
much experience in the common acadamies
that nothing is lost in this institution with
respect to manners and morals. Notwith'
. standing the number of the pupils, the dis
cpline in fact may be such as to product
the habit of greater proprety and dclicacl
Of demeanor. We mention these particu
lars now. merely to excite public atten
tion to the subject; sincerely wishing tina
the good example of New-York, in the for
nation of the Female High School, may b
followed here as readily and beneficially a


it has been in the case of the High Schoo


for boys.


PhNadeihhia Nat. Ga-.

1t is with regret we state, that the ship
Chancellor, Capt. Baker, which was, few
DAYS since, despatched from N. York, laden
with provisions for the suffering Greeks, ex-
pcricnced heavy gale, after being short
time at sea. and was compelled to put back
to repair damages. Her deck was complete
" swept of every thing, and two Of the sea-
men considerably injured. The Chancellor
will be repaired and ref,'ed Immediately
and proceed on her voyage to Napoli di Ro-
mania.

full articles.headline: For the Uiimiagtonian,
full articles.article:
TO MISS Il,
Who sa,u in Church raise her eyes toccards He
oh, Lady! when saw thy eyes
Ras'd meekly to the vault above;
And fix their gaze upon the skies,
They seemed to beam a soul love;
A soul endued with every grace
That can enrich the human face.
felt (it was sacred glow
A holy calm perrade my breast.
That babe my spirits lightest flow,
Pass sweetly in untroubled rest,


And bid each wayward care depart,
That nestled in my youthful heart,
And when the herald ofthc Lord,
Proclaimed the Gospel truths as given
And feeling dwelt upon the word,
The mandate of the God Of ofl,eaven,--
o! then ChriStiun'S hope divine,
Seemd cherish'd in that soul Of thine
And as gazed intent on thee,
l felt passing throe of bliss,
Then mouIn'd TO think it could not be
Continued in world like this,


Where every source OF pleasure here,
Is mingled with c6'iction's tear.
Yes, lady, fate doth bid me say,
Ere long ! go, and know not where's
Vet oft will recall the day


saw thee thus engaged in prayer


O, yes, and then this soul oi mine,
viii ask blessing down on thine.


ERAEBTWINF SiNsTREL

full articles.headline: Take Notice.

The Subscriber being about to change his bus.

JOHN RICE.

full articles.headline: Cl1RE EOR DRuNKENNEsS.
full articles.article:
The cure for intemperance, advertised in
most of our city papers, has produced good
many inquiries as to its real effect and utill-
ty. The editor of the New York Observer
mentions for the satisfaction of his distant
correspondents, several cases OF complete
cure following the use of the medicine, One
of these was that of woman between SO and
90 years of age, who had been incorporate
tor 25 years, and who. on taking the medi-
cine four times, lost all desire tor intoHcat-
ing liquors. Another was that of silver
smith, who found the remedy so ettectual,
that he presented the Doctor a set OF silver
spoons in addition to the usual fee. A third
is that of a man whose wife gave the medi-
cine to a neighbor where her husband used
to call for his liquor, with request that 1t
might be mixed with his drink. a few
draughts at different times made the man
saw that he did "not know what was the
matter with him, but somehow he was not
dry" 1t is said that taking the medicine
once or twice is commonly sufficient; but
that in some obstinate Cases it has failed to
effect a cure.

A New York paper states that the Brit
ish schooner Morning Star, arrived there on
Sunday last, aed was ordered off Immediate
ly by the Revenue officers.

Yyon, who lately published his Journal OF the
northern expedition while in command OF
one Of Capt. Parrv's ships, has met with sc.
yere rcverses Of fortune. Having received

At Hovhcad, he lost his Journal, maps, and
every thing he had Soon after landing, he
was informed of the death OF his amiable and
accomplished wife.

Ostrich Hurting in .4rabia.-Ostrich hun
ing is curious amusement of the Arabs
Twenty mounted on the horses ofthe deser
which are as transcendent among horse
as the herice is among camels, proceed
The windward in quest of an ostrich trac
and when thev have found enc, follow


with the utmost rapiditv, keeping at the dl
tance Of half mile from one another. III
ostrich, fatigued with running against Il
wind, which beats against his wings, tur


about to the hunters and attempts to pen


trate their lines but thev surround him, al


all at once fire On the bird; when he fal


Without this address they could never tai


the ostrich, which, tho destitute of the po'


er ottlving, surpassess in running the swii


est animal

urtlay. that the water in the Schuylkill Ca

A great public sale OF American mann'dc-
turcd goods, took place last week in Boston.
1t is said that the articles were in great va
riety and of superior workmanship. The
broad cloths, cassimcrcs, tlannels and satin
etts, were in great quantities. OF cotton
goods sheetng, shirtings and printed cali
Goes, there was also an extensive assortment.
Some of them very hnc, and the colours and
figures of the prints very good. Articles OF
glass s-ware and cabinet furniture were MI
merous; and some fine ware in imitation OF
China, was offered. There were, likewise,
great quantities of wool, leather and shoes
The sales, we understand, were generally
made at fair prices.

The first corner stone Ct the Pennsylvania
State Canal was laid at Harrisburg last
week, with masonic ceremonies, IN the
presence of the members of the legislature
and the masonic fraternity OF the vicinity,
who. together with the Governor, heads OF
departments, and several distinguished vls,
itors. among whom were Governor Carroll
OF Tennessee, aud Messrs. Findlay and
Marks. oe the United States Senate, march
ed in procession. from the State Capitol to
the canal. A short and appropriate address
was delivered on the occasion. by Joseph
Rinter. Esq. the Speaker of the House OF
Representatives.
